the qustion: Hypertension is defined as SBP ≥140 mm Hg or DBP ≥90 mm Hg on three separate occasions.
explanation: JNC 7 defines hypertension as SBP ≥140 or DBP ≥90 on three separate visits.

the qustion: The 2017 ACC/AHA guidelines define hypertension as SBP ≥130 mm Hg or DBP ≥80 mm Hg.
explanation: ACC/AHA 2017 lowered the diagnostic threshold to 130/80 mm Hg.

the qustion: Each 20 mm Hg systolic or 10 mm Hg diastolic increase doubles cardiovascular risk.
explanation: Risk of major CV events doubles with every 20/10 mm Hg increment.

the qustion: Hypertension is an independent risk factor for ischemic cardiovascular events.
explanation: Elevated BP alone increases risk of ischemic heart disease and stroke.

the qustion: Globally, hypertension affects more than 1.2 billion people.
explanation: Over 1.2 billion individuals worldwide have elevated BP.

the qustion: More than 50% of people with hypertension remain undertreated.
explanation: Over half of hypertensive patients do not achieve control.

the qustion: Isolated systolic hypertension is SBP ≥140 mm Hg and DBP <90 mm Hg.
explanation: Definition per JNC 7 classification.

the qustion: Isolated diastolic hypertension is SBP <140 mm Hg and DBP ≥90 mm Hg.
explanation: Definition per JNC 7 classification.

the qustion: Hypertensive urgency is BP >180/120 mm Hg with acute end-organ damage.
explanation: Urgency has no end-organ damage; emergency does.

the qustion: Hypertensive emergency is BP >180/120 mm Hg with acute end-organ damage.
explanation: Emergency is defined by severe elevation plus organ injury.

the qustion: Primary (essential) hypertension accounts for about 90% of cases.
explanation: Essential HTN makes up 90%; secondary is ~10%.

the qustion: Secondary hypertension accounts for 5–10% of cases.
explanation: Secondary causes are found in ~5–10% of hypertensive patients.

the qustion: Onset of hypertension before age 30 suggests secondary HTN.
explanation: Early-onset HTN (<30 years) raises suspicion for secondary causes.

the qustion: Obesity, sedentary lifestyle, alcohol, and high sodium intake contribute to essential hypertension.
explanation: These modifiable factors promote primary HTN.

the qustion: Pheochromocytoma is a cause of secondary hypertension.
explanation: Catecholamine-secreting tumors can elevate BP.

the qustion: Obstructive sleep apnea is not associated with secondary hypertension.
explanation: OSA is a recognized reversible cause of secondary HTN.

the qustion: NSAIDs and oral contraceptives can worsen blood pressure.
explanation: These drugs can induce or exacerbate HTN.

the qustion: JNC 7 recommends the same BP threshold for all adult ages.
explanation: JNC 7 uses ≥140/90 for adults regardless of age.

the qustion: JNC 8 recommends treatment threshold SBP ≥150 mm Hg in patients ≥60 years.
explanation: JNC 8 raised the target to <150/90 for age ≥60.

the qustion: USPSTF recommends annual HTN screening for adults ≥40 years.
explanation: Annual screening is advised for those ≥40 or high-risk.

the qustion: Out-of-office measurements are optional and not recommended by USPSTF before diagnosis.
explanation: USPSTF gives an “A” recommendation to confirm HTN with out-of-office readings.

the qustion: Home BP ≥135/85 mm Hg is diagnostic of hypertension.
explanation: Home-based thresholds differ from office values.

the qustion: ABPM daytime average >135/85 and nighttime >125/75 mm Hg defines hypertension.
explanation: ABPM criteria use lower thresholds at night.

the qustion: Masked hypertension has lower CV risk than sustained hypertension.
explanation: Masked HTN risk ≈ sustained HTN risk.

the qustion: White-coat hypertension carries minimal increase in CV risk.
explanation: White-coat HTN risk is only slightly elevated.

the qustion: Initial HTN evaluation includes CBC, UA, fasting glucose, BUN/Cr, electrolytes, TSH, lipid profile, and ECG.
explanation: These tests screen for comorbidities and secondary causes.

the qustion: Plasma renin activity is a routine test for all newly diagnosed hypertension.
explanation: Renin testing is reserved for suspected secondary HTN.

the qustion: Lifestyle modification is first-line treatment for stage 1 hypertension.
explanation: Non-pharmacologic measures are foundational.

the qustion: The DASH diet emphasizes fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat dairy.
explanation: DASH = Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension.

the qustion: The DASH diet recommends sodium intake <1500 mg/day.
explanation: Lower sodium enhances BP reduction on DASH.

the qustion: Weight loss of 10 kg reduces SBP by 5–20 mm Hg.
explanation: Weight reduction yields substantial SBP drop.

the qustion: Exercise 3–4×/week for 40 min/session lowers BP by 4–9 mm Hg.
explanation: Moderate-vigorous activity benefits BP control.

the qustion: Potassium supplements are routinely recommended to treat hypertension.
explanation: Supplement evidence is insufficient; focus on diet.

the qustion: Smoking cessation and alcohol moderation aid blood pressure control.
explanation: Reducing these risk factors lowers BP.

the qustion: Garlic supplements are proven to reduce blood pressure.
explanation: Current evidence does not support routine use.

the qustion: Pharmacologic therapy for patients ≥60 years begins at SBP ≥150 or DBP ≥90 mm Hg.
explanation: Grade A recommendation for age ≥60.

the qustion: For patients aged 30–60, therapy starts at SBP ≥140 or DBP ≥90 mm Hg.
explanation: Guideline cutoff for <60 years.

the qustion: ACE inhibitors are a first-line drug class for hypertension management.
explanation: ACEIs are foundational unless contraindicated.

the qustion: Beta-blockers are preferred initial therapy for essential hypertension.
explanation: BBs are not first-line without other indications.

the qustion: Thiazide diuretics are recommended initial therapy in African-American patients.
explanation: JNC 8 advises thiazides or CCBs for African-Americans.

the qustion: ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy.
explanation: ACEIs carry teratogenic risk and are avoided.

the qustion: ACE inhibitors often cause a persistent dry cough.
explanation: Bradykinin accumulation leads to cough.

the qustion: ARBs cause cough at the same rate as ACE inhibitors.
explanation: ARBs have lower rates of cough and angioedema.

the qustion: Calcium channel blockers are classified into dihydropyridines and non-dihydropyridines.
explanation: CCBs include amlodipine (dihydro) and verapamil (non-dihydro).

the qustion: Peripheral edema is a common side effect of dihydropyridine CCBs.
explanation: Dihydropyridines cause arteriolar dilation and edema.

the qustion: Thiazide diuretics can cause hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, and hyperglycemia.
explanation: Thiazides have multiple metabolic side effects.

the qustion: Loop diuretics are preferred in patients with GFR <30 mL/min.
explanation: Loops remain effective even at low GFR.

the qustion: Spironolactone is indicated for resistant hypertension even without confirmed hyperaldosteronism.
explanation: Low-dose spironolactone often helps resistant HTN.

the qustion: Initial combination therapy is recommended when BP >160/100 mm Hg.
explanation: Stage 2 HTN often requires two agents at once.

the qustion: Bedtime dosing of one antihypertensive (not diuretic) may improve control.
explanation: Nighttime administration can enhance nocturnal BP dip.

the qustion: Beta-blockers are contraindicated in asthma and COPD.
explanation: Non-selective BBs worsen bronchospasm.

the qustion: Metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily is a typical starting dose for HTN.
explanation: Metoprolol succinate starts at 12.5–25 mg daily.

the qustion: In resistant HTN, first exclude pseudo-resistance by accurate measurement and adherence assessment.
explanation: Confirm BP technique and adherence before labeling resistance.

the qustion: Primary aldosteronism screening is mandatory in all HTN patients.
explanation: Screen only if suspected (e.g., hypokalemia, resistant HTN).

the qustion: NSAIDs can interfere with antihypertensive efficacy.
explanation: NSAIDs reduce diuretic and ACEI effects.

the qustion: Resistant HTN is defined as BP above goal on ≥3 optimally dosed medications including a diuretic.
explanation: This is the standard definition of resistant HTN.

the qustion: Hypertensive emergencies most commonly present with acute pulmonary edema and cerebral infarction.
explanation: These are among the most frequent emergency presentations.

the qustion: Hypertensive urgency should be managed with rapid IV therapy.
explanation: Urgency is managed with oral agents over hours, not IV.

the qustion: In hypertensive emergency, reduce BP by no more than 25% in first hour.
explanation: Avoid rapid drops to prevent ischemia.

the qustion: Elderly patients often have isolated systolic hypertension.
explanation: Isolated systolic HTN is common after age 50.

the qustion: In elderly with HTN and CKD, ACE inhibitors are preferred unless contraindicated.
explanation: ACEIs protect kidney function in CKD.

the qustion: African-American patients respond better to ACE inhibitors than thiazides.
explanation: Thiazides and CCBs are more effective initial agents.

the qustion: In pregnant patients, methyldopa and labetalol are safe first-line agents.
explanation: These drugs have established safety profiles in pregnancy.

the qustion: Hydralazine is contraindicated in pregnancy due to fluid retention.
explanation: Hydralazine can be used but has tachycardia side effects.

the qustion: When to refer a hypertensive patient: resistant HTN, suspicion of secondary cause, HTN emergency, onset <30 years, or worsening control.
explanation: These are standard referral indications.

the qustion: Which organization defines stage 1 HTN as ≥130/80 mm Hg?
explanation: ACC/AHA 2017 lowered the stage 1 threshold to 130/80 mm Hg.

the qustion: Which reading indicates isolated diastolic hypertension?
explanation: SBP <140 with DBP ≥90 defines isolated diastolic HTN.

the qustion: A clinic BP of 185/115 mm Hg without organ damage is classified as:
explanation: Urgency is severe HTN without end-organ damage.

the qustion: Which is NOT a cause of secondary hypertension?
explanation: Osteoarthritis does not cause HTN.

the qustion: Which initial lab is optional rather than routine in HTN workup?
explanation: Aldosterone testing is for suspected secondary HTN.

the qustion: Home BP monitoring should record measurements for how many days?
explanation: Seven-day home monitoring is recommended, discarding day 1.

the qustion: ABPM daytime readings occur every:
explanation: ABPM measures every 15–30 min while awake.

the qustion: Which diet is richest in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy?
explanation: DASH emphasizes produce and low-fat dairy.

the qustion: Which lifestyle change yields the largest SBP reduction?
explanation: Weight loss (10 kg) lowers SBP by 5–20 mm Hg.

the qustion: Which supplement is recommended for hypertension control?
explanation: Supplements lack strong evidence for HTN control.

the qustion: Which agent is first-line for a pregnant hypertensive patient?
explanation: Methyldopa has a well-established safety profile.

the qustion: Which thiazide diuretic has the longest half-life?
explanation: Chlorthalidone is longer-acting among thiazides.

the qustion: Which CCB is non-dihydropyridine?
explanation: Diltiazem (and verapamil) are non-dihydropyridines.

the qustion: Which ACE inhibitor dose is incorrect?
explanation: Perindopril max is 10 mg daily, not 40 mg.

the qustion: Which side effect is most characteristic of ACE inhibitors?
explanation: ACE inhibitor–induced cough is due to bradykinin.

the qustion: Which drug class is preferred in African‐American hypertension without CKD?
explanation: Thiazides or CCBs are preferred first-line in this group.

the qustion: Which medication is contraindicated in bilateral renal artery stenosis?
explanation: ACEIs can worsen renal function in bilateral stenosis.

the qustion: What is the target BP reduction timeframe for urgency?
explanation: BP should be lowered over hours in urgency.

the qustion: Which drug is used orally for HTN urgency?
explanation: Oral captopril or amlodipine is used in urgency.

the qustion: Which organ is least affected in hypertensive emergency?
explanation: Skin seldom shows acute damage in hypertensive crises.

the qustion: On JNC 8, the BP goal for patients <60 years is <140/90 mm Hg.
explanation: JNC 8 sets <140/90 for patients <60.

the qustion: Which measure is NOT part of clinical evaluation of HTN?
explanation: Bone density is not routine in HTN workup.

the qustion: Which finding suggests possible secondary HTN?
explanation: Nocturia and low K hint at primary aldosteronism.

the qustion: Which is a non-modifiable risk factor for hypertension?
explanation: Age is non-modifiable; others are lifestyle factors.

the qustion: Which antihypertensive class improves outcomes post-MI?
explanation: ACEIs reduce mortality after myocardial infarction.

the qustion: Which is the best initial therapy for HTN in CKD with proteinuria?
explanation: ACEIs slow CKD progression in proteinuric patients.

the qustion: Which antihypertensive is safest in asthma patients?
explanation: Metoprolol is β1-selective, less bronchoconstrictive.

the qustion: Which direct vasodilator is used for resistant HTN?
explanation: Minoxidil is a potent vasodilator for resistant cases.

the qustion: Which agent is NOT titrated to maximum dose before adding a second drug?
explanation: Strategy B adds second drug before maxing first; others titrate first.

the qustion: Which complication is a form of microvascular change in HTN?
explanation: Hyaline arteriolosclerosis affects small vessels.

the qustion: Subarachnoid hemorrhage is a possible hypertensive emergency complication.
explanation: Severe HTN can precipitate cerebral hemorrhages.

the qustion: Hypertensive retinopathy includes papilledema and cotton-wool spots.
explanation: Retinal changes reflect acute end-organ damage.

the qustion: Left ventricular hypertrophy is a macrovascular complication.
explanation: LVH is an organ response but not classified as macrovascular change.

the qustion: Chronic kidney disease is a common complication of hypertension.
explanation: Long-standing HTN damages renal vasculature.

the qustion: HTN emergency with acute pulmonary edema is best managed with IV nitroprusside.
explanation: Pulmonary edema requires nitroglycerin or loop diuretics plus IV vasodilator.

the qustion: Resistant HTN should prompt referral after 6 months of failed treatment.
explanation: Specialist referral is advised if BP uncontrolled after six months.

the qustion: Universal screening for secondary causes is recommended for all hypertensives.
explanation: Screen selectively based on clinical clues.

the qustion: Hypertensive emergency commonly features chest discomfort from myocardial ischemia.
explanation: ACS can present during hypertensive crises.

the qustion: In resistant HTN, spironolactone is added when K+ >4.5 mEq/L.
explanation: Low-dose spironolactone is effective if K+ is safe.

the qustion: Which is a compelling indication for ACE inhibitor use in HTN?
explanation: ACEIs protect kidneys in diabetics with proteinuria.

the qustion: Which agent is preferred for HTN in heart failure with reduced EF?
explanation: ACEIs improve survival in HFrEF.

the qustion: What is the first-line drug for hypertension in pregnancy?
explanation: Methyldopa has best safety record in pregnancy.

the qustion: Which antihypertensive is safest in African-American patients with CKD?
explanation: ACEIs are recommended in CKD regardless of race.

the qustion: Which drug class is most likely to cause hyperuricemia?
explanation: Thiazides and loops can raise uric acid levels.
